What is your favourite food?
Talking about different types of food
Ingredients
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
Good morning. What can I get for you?
I'm going to a picnic later and need some [k]fruit[/k]. What have you got that's tasty?
Well, we've got some lovely [k]cherries[/k], just in today. And some tasty [k]peaches[/k].
OK, a kilo of each please. And I'd better get some [k]apples[/k] too. Not everyone likes cherries and peaches.
No problem. Two kilos? Also, we've got some fresh [k]orange[/k] juice if you'd like. It's cold too.
That'd be nice. They say it's going to be hot today. A perfect day for a picnic.
Yes, it sure is. That'll be 6.50 in total, please.
Here you go. Thanks a lot for your help. Bye.
Greengrocer
Helen
Select the correct option.
Select the words in the correct order.
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
Which kinds of fruit do you like most?
My favourite fruit is strawberries, but I also like bananas and pineapples. My least favourite fruit is oranges.
Cooking at home
Can you read the [k]recipe[/k] to me? My hands are messy.
Sure, no problem. Where are you up to? Have you [k]added[/k] the onions yet?
Yes, a couple of minutes ago. I think I have to [k]stir[/k] in the spices next, but I can't remember.
That's right, it says to [k]mix[/k] them together first and then [k]stir[/k] them into the vegetables before adding the tomatoes.
Ah, it smells really nice. OK. What's next?
It says you need to [k]wash[/k] and [k]peel[/k] the potatoes. Then [k]boil[/k] them while the sauce cooks.
It all sounds nice and easy. I hope it tastes good.
I'll set the table in a minute. Do you want to [k]serve[/k] it up here or in the dining room?
James
Claire
Grammar: Probability
The speaker is sure about their prediction.
We'll probably arrive at about 6 o'clock.
True or false?
It definitely won't rain this afternoon.
Maybe we'll be able to go for a walk.
With will and won't we can show that things are more or less probable by using adverbials like definitely, probably and maybe.
Definitely has the strongest meaning and shows that we are sure about what we're saying.
It definitely won't rain tomorrow.
Probably shows that we think something is likely, but is less sure than 'definitely'
It probably won't rain tomorrow.
Maybe is used to say that we are less sure about something.
Maybe it will rain tomorrow.
The speaker is not completely sure about their prediction.
It may be difficult to find a parking space.
We might be better to take the bus.
It'll definitely be a great party.
We use the verbs may and might to say that there is a possibility that something will happen. They are less sure than using 'will' and 'won't'

It might be a fun party.
It will be a fun party.
[k]We[/k] [k]will[/k] [k]definitely[/k] [k]go back[/k] [k]to that wonderful restaurant.[/k]
[k]We[/k] [k]definitely[/k] [k]won't[/k] [k]be coming here[/k] [k]again.[/k]
[k]I'll[/k] [k]probably[/k] [k]have[/k] [k]the roast Chicken.[/k]
The adverbs probably and definitely usually come after will but before won't:

We will probably visit them this year.
She'll definitely leave soon.
They probably won't arrive on time.
We definitely won't go there again.
[k]Maybe[/k] [k]I'll[/k] [k]see[/k] [k]the Queen[/k] [k]in London.[/k]
[k]He[/k] [k]may[/k] [k]be able to[/k] [k]help you[/k] [k]with the project.[/k]
[k]They[/k] [k]might[/k] [k]want[/k] [k]to meet you[/k] [k]first.[/k]
The adverb maybe usually comes at the beginning of a clause:
Maybe we'll go out later.
We don't usually use the adverbs 'probably', 'definitely' and 'maybe' with the verbs may and might:

We might go out later. 
not* <strike>We probably might go...</strike>
The food delivery [k]will probably[/k] arrive before 7 o'clock.
will might
